mn23:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn23:3.3: Now at that time Venerable Kassapa the Prince was staying in the Blind Man’s Grove.
mn23:3.4: Then, late at night, a beautiful deity, lighting up the entire Blind Man’s Grove, went up to Kassapa,
mn23:4.1: “Monk, monk! This ant-hill fumes by night and flames by day.
mn23:4.3: ‘Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.4: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a bar: ‘A bar, sir!’
mn23:4.7: Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.8: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a bullfrog:
mn23:4.12: Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.13: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a forked path:
mn23:4.17: Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.18: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a box:
mn23:4.22: Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.23: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a tortoise:
mn23:4.27: Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.28: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw an axe and block:
mn23:4.32: Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.33: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a lump of meat:
mn23:4.37: Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’
mn23:4.38: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a dragon:
mn23:4.41: ‘Leave the dragon! Do not disturb the dragon!
mn23:5.1: Mendicant, go to the Buddha and ask him about this riddle. You should remember it in line with his answer.
mn23:5.2: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to this riddle except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.”
mn23:5.3: That is what that deity said.
mn23:6.1: Then, when the night had passed, Kassapa went to the Buddha,
mn23:6.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
mn23:6.3: and and told him what had happened. Then he asked:
mn23:6.15: “Sir, what is the ant-hill? What is the fuming by night and flaming by day? Who is the brahmin, and who the sage? What are the sword, the digging, the bar, the bullfrog, the forked path, the box, the tortoise, the axe and block, the lump of meat? And what is the dragon?”
mn23:7.1: “Mendicant, ‘ant-hill’ is a term for this body made up of the four elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
mn23:8.1: Thinking and considering all night about what you did during the day—
mn23:8.2: this is the fuming at night.
mn23:8.3: The work you apply yourself to during the day by body, speech, and mind after thinking about it all night—
mn23:8.4: this is the flaming by day.
mn23:9.1: ‘Brahmin’ is a term for the Realized One, the Perfect One, the fully awakened Buddha.
mn23:9.2: ‘Sage’ is a term for the trainee mendicant.
mn23:10.1: ‘Sword’ is a term for noble wisdom.
mn23:10.2: ‘Digging’ is a term for being energetic.
mn23:11.2: ‘Throw out the bar’ means ‘give up ignorance,
mn23:11.3: Take up the sword, sage, and dig.’
mn23:12.1: ‘Bullfrog’ is a term for anger and distress.
mn23:12.2: ‘Throw out the bullfrog’ means ‘give up anger and distress’ …
mn23:13.1: ‘A forked path’ is a term for doubt.
mn23:13.2: ‘Throw out the forked path’ means ‘give up doubt’ …
mn23:14.1: ‘Box’ is a term for the five hindrances, that is:
mn23:14.2: the hindrances of sensual desire, ill-will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
mn23:14.3: ‘Throw out the box’ means ‘give up the five hindrances’ …
mn23:15.1: ‘Tortoise’ is a term for the five grasping aggregates, that is:
mn23:15.2: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
mn23:15.3: ‘Throw out the tortoise’ means ‘give up the five grasping aggregates’ …
mn23:16.1: ‘Axe and block’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation:
mn23:16.2: Sights cognizable by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Sounds cognizable by the ear …
mn23:16.8: Touches cognizable by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
mn23:16.9: ‘Throw out the axe and block’ means ‘give up the five kinds of sensual stimulation’ …
mn23:17.1: ‘Lump of flesh’ is a term for desire with relishing.
mn23:17.2: ‘Throw out the lump of flesh’ means ‘give up desire with relishing’ …
mn23:18.1: ‘Dragon’ is a term for a mendicant who has ended the defilements.
mn23:18.2: This is the meaning of: ‘Leave the dragon! Do not disturb the dragon!
mn23:19.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn23:19.2: Uplifted, Venerable Kassapa the Prince approved of what the Buddha said.
